author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: NJAC setback: Government stung, all-party meet likely
text:
NEW DELHI: Even as the government on Friday called the Supreme Court order striking down the NJAC a setback to parliamentary sovereignty and is likely to call an all-party meeting to discuss the matter, it was not sure of getting the backing of opponents should it approach Parliament anew for a reiteration that the collegium system deserved to be junked.
"Parliamentary sovereignty has received a setback today," Union communications minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said.
Prasad, who as law minister piloted the bill, emphasized that the SC itself had recognized that there was "something wrong" with the collegium system and that it needed to be fixed.
While the government did not conceal its frustration with the order, it did not seem to be sure of the backing of all political parties for a fresh effort by Parliament to end the monopoly judges have over appointments to higher judiciary. Although enacted under the NDA, the 99th Constitution amendment for setting up the NJAC marked the fruition of a process which had started under the UPA for restoring to executive the say it had in the appointment of members of higher judiciary.
However, with tensions running high between the government and the opposition, the Centre seems wary that sections of opposition, particularly Congress, may not agree to back it in any standoff with the judiciary.
The estimate stems from Congress's opposition to the GST bill, another legislation conceived under the UPA, and could have been strengthened further by the main opposition party's statement terming the SC order an expression of lack of confidence in the government.
The government is likely to gauge the mood by starting consultations with political parties and following that up by convening an all-party meeting to examine the feasibility of a fresh shy at the collegium system which it considers to be at odds with the spirit of the Constitution.
Sources in the government said while the Constitution clearly provided for the primacy of the executive in the appointment of judges, judiciary wrested the power and turned it into its prerogative. "From the position where judiciary had a collaborative and consultative role, we were brought to a situation where the judges have not just acquired primacy but, in fact, an exclusive say. This is not a case of simple overreach. They subverted the original constitutional design to come up with something different," said a top ranking government source.
He also said the SC's grudging acknowledgement that the collegium system had not worked well and needed to be fixed also raised the vexed question as to whose job should it be to enact the law needed for the purpose.
